There were also a lot of great leaders in the organization to learn from. However, like any large organization it can be highly political and tough to navigate effectively at times but doable. 

The Brandon complex has most things you will need during the day. This includes a dining facility with multiple restaurants and food choices. A banking or ATM machine. An onsite doctor's office was really convenient and a tremendous time saver. There was also an onsite gym with lockers and shower facilities as nice as any top-rated gym in the area. The benefits were also really quite good.

Most of the building/complex was organized or structured as a hoteling setup (call center-like). The space is very attractive. You work in large groups at long tables very close to one another. You are given a small locker to keep your personal items in and can't keep personal items in your workspace. The table chairs and workspace were ergonomic and nice. Finding a quiet place to concentrate was a challenge at times.
cons:
Not a con for everyone. It just did not work for me. 

People work close together and noise levels were significant in my area. I had an auditory processing condition making it difficult to hear people on the phone due to the background noise. I purchased special headphones but they didn't help a great deal. I was not comfortable seeking an accommodation for this.

If privacy or being able to have a personal space is important to you this is could be a negative and worth consideration. Hoteling is not for everyone. At the time working home for Tampa employees was not an option.

Navigating the organization can be challenging and political. Getting things done quickly can be challenging. This includes getting access to resources needed for your job. Speaking up can be tricky and fraught with peril. Be very mindful of who you direct request/s to...and how you make that request. Optics are important.

I worked for Citi during a time of significant departmental change. I really enjoyed the people I worked with outside of the environment.

A company that definitely tries to incorporate diversity and inclusion into it's recruiting culture but still has a way to go in terms of creating an environment that feels like differences are at home.

Training

Equipment

Team Structure
Again, working from home during a pandemic has its limitations for team building/co-operation however my experience at Citi was that teams were very disjointed with little crossover. There was no real efforts to keep the team in touch and team meetings were a rarity. 

Work/Life Balance
There was definitely a culture of not being away from your computer at all during the hours of work which was only exacerbated by having to message when you left the desk/went for lunch. Felt almost like you were back in school having to ask permission to leave your desk.

Management
From speaking to people in other teams at Citi, along with my own experience, it seems like managers at Citi are told to manage through thinly veiled threats and aggression. I found that my manager was as nice as nice when talking directly, full of praise and advice, however when there was any official requirements such as probation the story was very different. Complete absence of human understanding for issues that people have going on outside of work.
